root@dell:~/scan/abyss# ./abyss -s www.t: why does this happen in ubuntu
and not in any other os
Probably becasue Ubuntu builds everything with a bunch of compile-time security options, which abyss is breaking.
In particular, it seems that it's trying to access memory weirdly.  If this is the intended behaviour, file a bug.
I'm not entirely sure, there's something on the ubuntu wiki, but I can't seem to find it.
And you can't turn it off, it's how the abyss package was compiled.  You should file a bug against the abyss package.
can I install another gcc instead of ubuntu's because I believe ubuntu's gcc installs the stack protection
As far as I'm aware, it's a compile time option to use the stack protection.
That's awesome.  What are these programs you're trying to run, that abuse the stack in such a fashion? ;)
You've built this from source yourself, or is it a package from the Ubuntu archives?
If they're packages from the archives, you should file bugs against them, since stack protection is enabled at build-time (and I don't believe you can disable it at run-time)
Then you need to file bugs, since you can't disable the protections at run time.
Or you could apt-get source the packages, edit the debian/rules files, and rebuild them.
